awd_titl_txt: RUI: Fundamental Investigation Towards Phosphorus Recovery Through Organophosphate Pesticide Degradation by Molybdate Complexes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Chemistry Division.  Pesticides and herbicides are used to kill weeds and insects, but these chemicals last a long time and can be found throughout the environment. These chemicals can be damaging to animals and humans, and have even been implicated in neurodegenerative diseases. Using basic chemistry techniques, this project from Professor Louis Kuo at Lewis and Clark College looks for ways to make these pesticides and herbicides safer.  A main ingredient in these chemicals is the element phosphorus. This project also investigates the use of non-toxic metals to collect, break down, safely recover, and transform the phosphate-based toxins for a new use.  Phosphorus is non-renewable and essential for life on earth, so recycling it is important for sustainability. This research lies at the interface of inorganic and organic chemistry, and uses a combination of experimental and computational techniques. Undergraduate researchers, high school students, and high school teachers participate in this project, while engaging in meaningful science within the context of safe environmental stewardship.

This research project addresses environmental toxin remediation and phosphorus recovery. Organophosphates (OP) are agricultural pesticides that are now ubiquitous in the environment. As such, there is a need for materials that degrade these OP pesticides in a practical fashion. This goal is more meaningful when the degraded OP pesticides are recovered as usable organophosphates since phosphorus is an essential but non-renewable resource.  This study focuses on using supported and solution=-phase molybdenum complexes that convert organophosphate toxins into commodity chemicals.  Specifically, the project examines how polystyrene-supported and picolinato (solution) complexes of molybdenum-peroxo compounds convert sulfur-containing organophosphate pesticides and the widely-used glyphosate herbicide (Roundup) into phosphate commodity chemicals. Several hypothetical routes involving reactive oxygen species are tested with spectroscopic studies on solution models and supported molybdenum-peroxo complexes.  In parallel with the experimental work there is a computational component using density functional theory that simulates the organophosphate reactions.  The goal is to predict and design better molybdenum complexes that accomplish the organophosphate degradation.  In this connection, the long term goal is to develop new supported and practical molybdenum-peroxo materials that degrade the organophosphate toxins into value-added materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This is the first time a supported molybdate-peroxide material carries out heterogeneous catalysis for degrading BOTH phosphonate and phosphorothioate pesticides

It revealed a new reactivity pattern for glyphosate (i.e. Roundup) degradation not seen before

The heterogeneous reactions have the solution analog 2 with similar reaction chemistries as the supported material.

This transformation is a feasible route for phosphorus recovery that does not rely on noxious phosphorus acids and it recycles two types of organphosphates into a usable phosphorus compound; this fulfills a national priority on phosphorus recovery.

The intermediates discovered in pesticide degradation is relevant in their life cycle under oxidative conditions. The molybdate materials degrade both phosphorothioate and phosphinate pesticides. One of the molybdenum materials enabled both herbicide and insectide degradation towards non-toxic products. Specifically, a novel chemical route was discovered that oxidatively degraded the insecticide diazinon into the commodity chemical diethyl phosphite with little or no toxic paraoxon product. In addition, the same material degraded the wide spectrum herbicide glyphosphate into phosphate. Aside from representing a form of phosphorus recovery from pesticide degradation, the fundamental chemical investigations revealed new pathways for both phosphorothioate and phosphinate chemistries that potentially take place in the environment. Certain intermediates in glyphosate degradation by the molybdenum materials mimicked the chemistry of the C-P lyase bacteria. This system is known to degrade phosphinates (i.e. glyphosate), so this fundamental chemistry may serve as a model for this enzyme. At the same time we now understand the chemical factors within the diazinon pesticide that contribute its degradation away from the toxic oxon form where the sulfur of the original phosphorothioate is replaced with oxygen. This potentially enables the design of less toxic sulfur-containing pesticides.

 

Briader Impacts:

The findings on these pesticidies have both public health and environmental implications. The development of glyphosate-resistant GMO has made it one of the most widely applied pesticide in the agricultural industry. As such, this herbicide has been found in all watersheds in the midwest and the U.S. accounts for one-sixth of the glyphosate usage in the world. In terms of public health, organophosphates are neurotoxins, and there is a correlation between insecticide levels in infants and poor cognitive development.  At the same time, studies on glyphosate have found it connected to honey bee navigation interference and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Therefore the investigation of factors that degrade phosphorothioate insectides (i.e. diazinon) and phosphinate herbicide has a broad public health impact especially if the fundamental investigations lay the foundation for the design on pesticides that degade into less harmful byproducts.

In that connection, another common theme for the degradation for these two pesticides is the development of a new polymer that address phosphorus recovery. There is a 30-40 year domestic supply of phosphorus and most of the global phosphate source is in the Western Sahara. The NSF has identified phosphorus recovery as a national priority since this element is the mainstay in agriculture and in the chemical industry. Given the prevalence of glyphosate in the field, its degradation into usable phosphate fertilizer represents an avenue to this goal. A new molybdenum-based polymer was found that converts both a phosphorothioate insecticide and phosphonate herbicide into commodity chemicals under relatively mild conditions.

Another broader impact of this work is the training of nine undergraduates, three high school students and one high school science teacher in key chemical aspects of environmental chemistry. This creates a pipeline of STEM students and teacher focused on chemical strategies towards environmental stewardship. All of these students are in graduate school or employed in STEM fields, and the high school students are majoring the sciences as well. There is also a DEI outreach in terms of recruiting under represented students into this project.


Last Modified: 04/19/2024
Modified by: Louis Y Kuo
